comment info:
1. My first reaction to this graph is how detailed it is. I noticed (and hardly ever realized) how competitive March Madness is. Total of 126 games were split by 64 men's teams and 64 women's teams. I see that Miami in both men's and women's tournaments made it to the quarterfinals. Also, the women's final game was higher than the men's final game. Looking at the graph overall, the lower number of seeds usually ends up winning the matches. 

2. I wonder how seeds are assigned as well as the concept as to why they exist in March Madness in the first place. Something that I also found quite interesting is the first four teams that played were in a separate bracket. Why is that?

4. March Madness 2023: How did it go?

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Grace Velazquez Good observations! You noticed that Miami had a men’s team and a women’s team make the elite-8. Do you think it is common for one school to be so successful in both tournaments in the same year? How could you investigate this question? You also noticed that the women’s championship game was higher scoring than the men’s championship game. Do women’s teams typically score more points than men’s team, or was the championship game an exception? The “first four” teams were added several years ago as a way to include more teams in the tournament. But the single-elimination brackets work best when there is a multiple-of-two number of teams (e.g., 16, 32, 64), so they added these games as a “pre-tournament” to make the field of 64. Maybe there will be a 128-team tournament in the future? Finally, seed are determined by a NCAA committee that looks at won-loss records and other ratings. Why do you think they look at more than just wins and losses?

name: EmilyAOSE
comment info:
Notice:
Both of these charts display the women’s and men’s brackets from the most recent March Madness. The charts display the points for each game as well as the rank of each of the schools. The bracket also labels each of the rounds and provides the dates which they had occurred above the matches. 

Wonder: 
I wonder how each of these teams are ranked before the tournament. I wonder why none of the teams which were ranked first were able to make it into the bracket, if they were predetermined to be the best. 

Observed:
I observed that while both teams had upsets within their brackets, the women’s brackets seemed to be much more consistent with rank. For instance, the final four of the women’s bracket included teams ranked: 1, 2, 1, and 3. However, the men’s final four consisted of lower ranked teams: 5, 9, 4, and 5. This indicates that the men’s bracket had more upsets in their bracket leading to lower ranked teams reaching the final four. I also observed that both of the teams that reached the final in both the men’s and women’s bracket were only one rank apart, with the women’s final being between teams ranked 2 and 3, and the men’s being 3 and 4. This resulted in a fairly evenly matched game.

Community:
Many people in my community watch March Madness and create their bracket predictions. This graph also showed that women’s basketball is just as entertaining as men’s basketball. 

Headline:
Brackets Busted: Men’s and Women’s March Madness

name: Nicole
comment info:
I noticed that both graphs have the same general format, with 64 initial teams cut in half each round. The seed numbers are also identical because there are four groups of 1-16. I also noticed that the teams are separated into four different regions, which are different for the women’s and men’s brackets. In the men’s bracket, the regions are south, east, midwest, and west. However, in the women’s bracket, they are separated into Greenville 1, Greenville 2, Seattle 3, and Seattle 4.

I wonder how the teams are placed into their corresponding seeds. For example, what makes the team have to play in the “First Four” group? Why do they have to play an extra game when the NCAA can select 64 teams? Also, where are all the games played? With so many teams and games, they must spread out the games to accommodate everyone. I also wonder how often lower seeds beat the higher seeds in general.

I am going to be a college freshman in the fall and I am interested in how well my college's sports performances are compared to other universities in the state. This graph made me realize how competitive college sports are and why many students become very excited when their college sports team makes it into the Final Four.   

“Madness Unleashed: Tracing NCAA Basketball”

The First Four – why do we have a First Four?  There is something very special about having 64 teams or, say, 128 teams or 256 or 512 or 1,024…  So, what do you do if you have 68 teams?  One answer is to have a First Four.  Can you think of another answer?

name: Colleen D. AOSE
comment info: I noticed that the women's bracket had slightly more predictable teams than the men's. Two number 1 seeds were in the Final Four, and the Championship game was played between the number 2 seed and the number 3 seed. I noticed a few upsets at the beginning of the tournament, but the championship match had the top teams in the country. What's very interesting is that this is the first year since 1985 that Stanford, UCONN, or Tennessee has not been in the Elite Eight. I wonder what this will mean for collegiate women's basketball growth in America. This bracket shows the growth of the game away from just the perennially dominant teams such as UCONN, Stanford, and Tennessee and towards up-and-coming programs such as South Carolina, LSU, and Iowa. The men's bracket had many more upsets, like FDU and Princeton. No number one seed was left in the tournament by the elite eight. The final four for last year’s tournament were Kansas, UNC, Villanova, and Duke, teams that are usually at the top of the NCAA. This year's final four consisted of San Diego State, Florida Atlantic University, UCONN, and Miami. Besides Connecticut, most of these teams rarely advanced to the Elite Eight. How will this affect college basketball and the transfer portal? Will dominant teams in the NCAA change dramatically or gradually? This affects me because I am a fan of men’s and women’s college basketball. My headline is “Crave the Chaos: the Madness of the NCAA March Tournament.”

name: Julius
comment info:
After looking at the round of 64, I noticed that that was the category that played the outermost ranked teams (rank #1 v rank #16, rank #2 v rank #15, and so on). After observing them I noticed that the more extreme female teams tended to have a larger spread in points compared to the more extreme male teams. After observing this data I recorded the point and averaged the 8 most largest ranked unbalanced games. The mean difference in scores between the 8 sets of women's' games was a point difference of 35.375 points while the mean difference in scores between the 8 sets of men's games was a point difference of 17.375. We can also observe that all of the sampled individual mens game differences fall beneath the women's point difference mean (35.375) and all of the sampled individual women's games fall above the men's point difference mean (17.375).

This makes me wonder why there is such an extreme difference in points. A larger mean difference in points would most likely mean that the variance in skill is higher. (Although my sport's knowledge is limited) I suspect that the higher viewership and profits give incentive for mens basketball to be a more competitive environment leading to a potential smaller variance in point spreads. 

More than half of my friends follow March Madness and enjoy watching the games. Although I am not as invested, it is interesting to see the games as a whole after they have been played through.

Whats going on in this graph?

A Spread in Skills

name: Julia
comment info:
The graph shows the match-ups and outcomes for each game in the 2023 NCAA basketball tournaments.  The only noticeable difference is the categories for which the tournament coordinators separated the teams in the first round.  The women’s bracket categories are Greenville 1, Greenville 2, Seattle 3, and Seattle 4 while the men’s bracket categories are South, Midwest, East, and West.  Another small difference is the duration for each tournament.  The men’s tournament was two days longer than the women’s tournament.  The graph’s most noticeable feature is the organization.  For each game, the graph shows the team names, score, standing, and game date.  The lines connecting the games provide an intuitive flow to indicate which team won and moved to the next round.  The graph highlights the championship game with a thick border.  I wonder why the women’s tournament categories are different, and how the coordinators chose the categories.  I play basketball, and our team created competing brackets, but Mississippi ruined my women’s bracket, and Princeton ruined my men’s bracket.
